The exact wording varies by state or country, but the core actions are mandated by the **FDA’s Pasteurized Milk Ordinance (PMO) – the “raw‑milk” annex**, by **state agricultural‑health statutes**, and by **international standards (e.g., Codex Alimentarius, EU Regulation 853/2004)**.  

I have grouped the process into **four phases** and added **typical time‑frames** based on documented outbreak investigations, state inspection reports, and academic case studies.  All dates are “best‑available averages”; actual timelines can be faster (if the farm is well‑prepared) or slower (if the lab is back‑logged or the regulator’s resources are stretched).

| Action | Who does it? | Why it matters | Typical deadline |
|--------|--------------|----------------|------------------|
| **a. Halt all raw‑milk sales and distribution** | Farm owner / manager; must be documented in writing (email, log‑book) | Prevents any further exposure while the source is investigated. | **Within 2 h** of receiving the result (most state statutes require “as soon as practicable”). |

| **c. Quarantine the bulk‑tank and all milk containers** | Farm staff | Prevents cross‑contamination of clean milk or equipment. | Immediate; documented in a “milk‑hold” log. |
